topic.title: [suggestion] ZIP export and import of (individual) sites
topic.body:
Title says it all.
Good for a more decentralized ZeroNet, makes it easier to share offline and online (without the ZeroNet network), and for backups.

topic.title: [suggestion] Offline mode
topic.body: Add `--offline` to disable networking, useful for browsing already downloaded websites.

topic.title: List of working ZeroNet proxies (access ZeroNet without ZeroNet)
topic.body:
Here's a list of working ZeroNet Proxies:
* https://fuckcf.cf
* https://zeronet.korso.win/
* https://onlyzero.net/
* https://bit.surf:43110
* https://proxy1.zeronet.functor.xyz:10443
* http://cvhb5yx2qdclb76m.onion (Tor Hidden Service)
* http://zero.btnova.org (no HTTPS)
* https://antnet.org/ (broken TLS certificate)

Down (?):
* https://zeronet.maxweiss.io

topic.title: [suggestion] Proof-of-work
topic.body:
Allow Zite owners to whitelist hashes of the user's public key that match certain prefix or suffix (e.g. by using Regular Expressions).
Like `'user_hash_regex': '^0000'`. Or maybe you could just use strings like `'user_hash_prefix': '0000'`
This would be useful for anonymous but still "rate-limited" user cert generation.

topic.title: Beaker Browser, an experimental peer-to-peer browser
topic.body:
Beaker Browser is an experimental browser for Mac OS X and Linux with peer-to-peer Web protocols (using Dat). 
* GitHub: https://github.com/beakerbrowser/beaker
* Website: https://beakerbrowser.com/
* Dat: https://datproject.org/

topic.title: uBlock Origin - An efficient blocker for Firefox, Chrome,  Edge and Opera.
topic.body:
The best free and open source (ad)blocker.
* GitHub: https://github.com/gorhill/uBlock
* [Firefox Extension](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/ublock-origin/)
* [Chrome Extension](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/ublock-origin/cjpalhdlnbpafiamejdnhcphjbkeiagm)
* [Edge Extension](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/store/p/app/9nblggh444l4)
* [Opera Extension](https://addons.opera.com/en/extensions/details/ublock/?display=en)

topic.title: [suggestion] Invite-based user registration
topic.body:
How I see this work:

`content.json` of the user directory (managed by Zite owner):
```
  "invites": [
    "11SVkYkmCCFyBCVUU7Qaj8SAhyVT7m6pS": {"invites_allowed": 10},
    "1889tLMuZze7YMshhe8u5h4NT4SSiA4PVB",
    "1A3eo1m9ouw9KupiePER5ZdajEaUQnUqq": {"invites_allowed": 0}
  ],
  "invitation_rules": {
    "invites_allowed": 5
  }
```
`data.json` of the user (managed by user):
```
  "invites": [
    "1669uhTeS1CptbLN8L88NVjP1BTgGMqk9W",
    "1674XymFPbmAXh78xEpt3Pehtko6i2kvtA",
    "1A3BvenLM5YXiyPoTrrhe4iMoeRmpwKWbV"
  ]
```

If the Zite owner sees a user that invites spammers it can ban the whole tree by adding 
```
  "invites": [
    "1A3eo1m9ouw9KupiePER5ZdajEaUQnUqq": {"invites_allowed": 0}
  ] 
```
to the `content.json` in the `users` directory.

topic.title: BitErrant attack - BitTorrent protocol SHA1 collision proof of concept
topic.body:
https://biterrant.io/

"The BitErrant attack is a fun little exploit that shows what can go wrong in the BitTorrent protocol when SHA1 collisions become reality.


SHA1 collisions resulting in chunks of the downloaded file become replaceable with a chunk that is completely different, corrupting the downloaded file OR triggering backdoor functionalities.


An attacker can alter the execution path of the executable by serving altered chunks when the victim is downloading the executable using the BitTorrent protocol.

Thank you good folks at Google and CWI for making SHA1 collision become a reality with the [SHAttered](http://www.shattered.io/) attack!"

1_1JHumjFpXMTtSgm1ygdHqsvL9321Z87NDc.body:
- **Use Tor Browser** (based on Firefox) https://torproject.org
- **Use Linux** ([Xubuntu](https://xubuntu.org/), [Fedora](https://getfedora.org/), [Debian](https://debian.org/), [Arch Linux](https://www.archlinux.org/))
  - Take a look at https://distrowatch.com/ for an overview of all Linux distributions
- **Use Firefox** with [uBlock Origin](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/ublock-origin/) & [HTTPS Everywhere](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/https-everywhere/) installed
  - Take a look at https://fixfirefox.com/ for more Firefox usage tips
- **Don't use anything prefixed with smart** (smartphone, smart TV, smart thermostat).
- **Don't use Google**
  - Use [DuckDuckGo](https://duckduckgo.com/), [Searx](https://github.com/asciimoo/searx/wiki/Searx-instances) or [StartPage](https://www.startpage.com/)
